images.caption: Figure 1:Core Motivation. We progressively integrate complementary information from metric measurements (accurate metrics) and relative predictions (completeness and fine details) to produce dense and fine-grained metric depth maps.

Figure 2:Prior Depth Anything.Considering RGB images, any form of depth priorùêÉpriorsubscriptùêÉprior\mathbf{D}_{\textrm{prior}}bold_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT prior end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and relative predictionùêÉpredsubscriptùêÉpred\mathbf{D}_{\textrm{pred}}bold_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pred end_POSTSUBSCRIPTfrom a frozen MDE model, coarse metric alignment first explicitly combines the metric data inùêÉpriorsubscriptùêÉprior\mathbf{D}_{\textrm{prior}}bold_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT prior end_POSTSUBSCRIPTand geometry structure inùêÉpredsubscriptùêÉpred\mathbf{D}_{\textrm{pred}}bold_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pred end_POSTSUBSCRIPTto fill the incomplete areas inùêÉpriorsubscriptùêÉprior\mathbf{D}_{\textrm{prior}}bold_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT prior end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Fine structure refinement implicitly merges the complementary information to produce the final metric depth map.
Figure 3:Qualitative comparisons with previous methods. The depth prior or error map is shown below each sample.
Figure 4:Error analysis on widely used but indeed noisy benchmarks[42,13].Redmeans higher error, whileblueindicates lower error.
